data.title: Debugger and runTimeArgs order
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: macos 10.12.1

I don't have nodejs installed locally on my machine, but I'm using the official docker image to run the typescript. I tried to setup VS Code to launch the docker image but the `--debug-brk` flag is injected before any of the arguments. Is there any way I could control the order of the arguments?

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use the following `launch.json`:

```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch Program",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/index.ts",
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "outFiles": [],
      "sourceMaps": true,
      "env": {
        "NODE_ENV": "development"
      },
      "outDir": "${workspaceRoot}/bin",
      "runtimeExecutable": "docker",
      "runtimeArgs": ["run", "-ti", "node:6.9.1"]
    }
  ]
}
```

2. Run the program in debug mode.

The console prints:

```bash
docker --debug-brk=35420 run -ti node:6.9.1 bin/index.js 
flag provided but not defined: --debug-brk
See 'docker --help'.
```

To run the application in docker that line should read instead:

```bash
docker run -ti node:6.9.1 bin/index.js --debug-brk=35420
```

data.title: Some SCSS items syntax coloring improperly scoped
Improve flow to get to a running debug session
data.body:
Investigation of the success rate of new users trying to start a debug session has shown that we loose ~25% at the environment picker and another ~25% once the launch.json is generated. At the same time debugging is among our user success experiences.

Some ideas that came up in discussions:
- Add a "More..." entry at the end of the environment picker that opens the extension viewlet with other debug adapters.
- Add more information to the 'debugMisconfiguration' event to be provided by the debug adapter to improve our understanding of what goes wrong.
- If there is no launch.json yet: Try to avoid the picker and/or the generated launch.json based on the currently opened file and launch a debug session directly.
- Improve the UX when the workbench did not open on a folder. (About half of all sessions.)

Part of the outcome of #15383.

data.title: Cannot set breakpoints where I choose
data.body: Every time that I try to set a breakpoint it automatically moves it to another point in my file. It should just set the breakpoint on the line that I choose not whatever it thinks is best. I chose line 307 here and it keeps moving it to line 316, which isn't even the same function. (You can see this at the bottom left of the screenshot). It should not be moving my breakpoint at all - VSCode Version: 1.7.2 - OS Version: OSX Sierra 10.12.1 - React-Native 0.30.0 - Node 6.9.1 - Babel-Register 6.11.6 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run Deugger 2. Add/Remove Some Code 3. Try to set a breakpoint

data.title: Support building Flatpak application bundles
data.body:
This adds support for building [Flatpak](http://flatpak.org) application bundles, which should be runnable on any Linux distribution with [Flatpak support](http://flatpak.org/getting.html).

New Gulp tasks are added to prepare a directory with the needed files (`vscode-linux-${arch}-prepare-flatpak`), assembling the Flatpak bundles (`vscode-linux-${arch}-flatpak`), and for cleaning the build directories (`clean-vscode-linux-${arch}-flatpak`). This mimics how the Debian and RPM package creation works. Hence, building an application bundle is done with:
 
```   
$ gulp vscode-linux-x64-flatpak
[...]
$ ls *.flatpak
com.visualstudio.code.oss-x86_64.flatpak
```

Installing and running the application is achieved with:

```
$ flatpak --user install --bundle com.visualstudio.code.oss-x86_64.flatpak
$ flatpak run com.visualstudio.code.oss
```

(Removing `--user` would install the application system-wide.)

The `org.freedesktop.Platform` runtime needs to be installed for running the application, and for making builds the `org.freedesktop.Sdk` runtime is needed as well. There are [installation instructions in the Flatpak website](http://flatpak.org/index.html#users); the short version is:

```
wget https://sdk.gnome.org/keys/gnome-sdk.gpg
flatpak --user remote-add --gpg-import=gnome-sdk.gpg gnome https://sdk.gnome.org/repo/
flatpak --user install org.freedesktop.Platform 1.4
flatpak --user install org.freedesktop.Sdk 1.4
```

The [flatpak-bundler](https://www.npmjs.com/package/flatpak-bundler) development dependency provides an asynchronous API to invoke `flatpak-builder`. The [gulp-image-resize](https://www.npmjs.com/package/gulp-image-resize) module is used to
incorporate scaling of the application icon to multiple sizes, and uses ImageMagick (or GraphicsMagick) under the hood, which is commonly available on most GNU/Linux distributions.

Instead of building the Electron dependencies, this reuses the    `io.atom.electron.BaseApp` ([source](https://github.com/endlessm/electron-flatpak-base-app)) bundle as base application. The contents of the base application are imported at build time, and then Electron and the prepared files added on top. The prebuilt base application will be fetched automatically using the URL specified in the `baseFlatpakref` attribute, and it is kindly hosted at Amazon S3 by [Endless Computers](https://endlessm.com/).

Merging this would tackle issue #7112.

data.title: Filter file-based recommendations to those relevant to the file
data.body:
When opening recommendations from the message for an opened file, the list of recommended extensions is shown in full, not filtered down and/or sorted to those relevant to the file the message originated from.

Only showing the relevant extensions would improve the user experience and impact of the feature.

Part of the outcome of #15383.

data.title: Revisit strategy for picking an existing window when opening a single file
data.body:
Currently the last active window is used, which can seem random to the user. It would make more sense to reuse a window opened on a parent folder of the file to open, if there is such a window.

We already have `"window.openFilesInNewWindow"` which doesn't seem to work in its default setting `true`. Rather than fix that, we should consider making `false` the default so the suggested change above gets used more often (currently the effective default).

For background: Only half of all sessions are opened on a folder, about 30% are opened on a single file.

Part of the outcome of #15383.

data.title: Use better recognizable icons for keymap extensions

![keymap-extension-icons](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9205389/20681925/92bf3dbe-b55a-11e6-9d68-15d27df4574a.png)

data.title: Remove automatic new untitled file in empty workbench
data.body:
From #15547:  I don't see an effect of the untitled file experiment on the number of times an untitled file is used. It appears that creating an untitled file is intuitively understood by new users. Also users don't create new files that frequently, they read/work on existing files much more often it seems, that reduces the value of the automatically opened new untitled file further.

Part of the outcome of #15383.

data.title: Dynamic code evaluation for vscode hacking
data.body:
The core feature which is keeping me with Emacs is its dynamic code evaluation property.

Whenever I want to change the editor behaviour, I open an empty buffer, I write some code, I evaluate it and it's ready to be used. I use the editor itself for a while and if I like the new functionality, I add it to my default configuration.

Is this even possible with Visual Studio Code? It would indeed speed up extension writing significantly.

The workflow I picture in my mind would be: opening an empty file, writing a bit on TrueScript language and evaluating it. If it works I'd add it to my personal extension. If I think it would be useful to the community I'd publish it in the Marketplace.

data.title: Don't translate Markdown.category
data.body:
**Bug**
The `Markdown.category` should not be translated.

**Fix**
Inline translation

Closes #16087

data.title: Cannot build VSCode from source following the 'How to contribute' instructions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Latest code from master branch
- OS Version: Windows 10 14965

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Follow the 'How to contribute' instructions and attempt to build VSCode (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute) 

I asked this on Stack Overflow but have not received any replies yet.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/40814033/over-1700-errors-compiling-vscode-what-is-configured-incorrectly

I get many errors (1700+) when I try to build using 'npm run watch', for instance:

    [17:40:59] Starting 'watch-client'...
    [17:41:25] Error: E:/src/git/vscode/extensions/css/server/src/languageModelCache.ts(22,21): Cannot find     name 'Date'.
    [17:41:25] Error: E:/src/git/vscode/extensions/css/server/src/languageModelCache.ts(23,15): Cannot find name 'Object'.
    [17:41:25] Error: E:/src/git/vscode/extensions/css/server/src/languageModelCache.ts(40,31): Cannot find name 'Date'.
    [17:41:25] Error: E:/src/git/vscode/extensions/css/server/src/languageModelCache.ts(44,80): Cannot find name 'Date'.
    [17:41:25] Error: E:/src/git/vscode/extensions/css/server/src/languageModelCache.ts(50,22): Cannot find name 'Number'.
    ...

I have Node 6.9.1 installed, Python 2.7.12, Windows SDK 10.0.14393.33, Visual Studio 2015 14.0.25421.03 (Update 3), .NET Framework 4.6.02006, npm 3.10.8.

I must be missing something basic but so far I haven't tracked it down. Is there a missing step in the instructions for contributing?

The full list of errors is here:
http://pastebin.com/wJgEQ18m

data.title: JIS (Japanese) Keyboard Layout: Define Keybinding popup window shows wrong key
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.1
- Keyboard layout: JIS (Japanese)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open keybindings.json
2. Press ⌘K ⌘K
3. Some of key combinations are shown as wrong key

Example of wrong combinations:

|Pressed|Expected|Actual|
|---|---|---|
|@|@|[|
|Shift+1|!|Shift+1|
|Shift+:|*|Shift+'|
|Shift+Cmd+:|Cmd+*|Shift+Cmd+;|

data.title: Improved sorting criteria for extensions
data.body:
We can currently sort extensions by rating or install count, both are not quite adequate for sorting by "popularity". Part of the problem is that the install count includes updates.

A (presumably additional) sort criteria useful for both "top 10" list and the extension viewlet should better reflect how popular an extension is at present - as opposed to over its entire lifespan.

With such a sort criteria we should hopefully be able to phase out some of our curated lists of extensions which take time to maintain and can be slow to pay tribute to the rising stars.

Related to #15159. Part of the outcome of #15383. /cc @joaomoreno @Tyriar

data.title: Paste into multiple cursors has edge case when number of lines equals number of cursors - 1
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy these three lines in their entirety:

```
aaa
bbb
ccc
```

2. Create a document:

```
test
test
test
test
```

3. Select all 4 instances of `text` with `cmd-D` so you get 4 cursors.
4. Paste.

Result:

```
aaa
bbb
ccc

```

Expected document:

```
aaa
bbb
ccc
aaa
bbb
ccc
aaa
bbb
ccc
aaa
bbb
ccc
```

This weird case seems to only happen if the number of cursors is the number of lines in the selection, plus one. I've been unable to reproduce if the selection contains less than three lines, however.

There is some discussion about this behaviour in #4996, which is about a different case.

data.title: [Intellisence] How to reference auto-fetched typings in my custom typings file?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Win10 x64

So now after the new auto-fetching of typings option was introduced structures like ``///<reference path="../nunjucks/index.d.ts" />`` obviously won't work in a custom ``.d.ts`` file if no such typings were installed manually. If I understand it correctly the auto-fetched typings reside under ``%APDATA%\Local\Microsoft\TypeScript\node_modules\@types\`` and these ``.d.ts`` contain tripple-slash refs with the key ``types`` (like ``/// <reference types="serve-static" />``). I couldn't find any documentation for that anywhere (much less in the [official ts docs](http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/triple-slash-directives.html)). Using such ref in my custom ``.d.ts`` ~doesn't seem to work, even~ only if I copy the whole ``node_modules\@types\[module_name]`` folder into the location where my custom typings file resides (and also after some time delay).

Is it even possible? If not then consider it as request. Like f.e.
```
///<reference path="${auto-fetched-typings}/nunjucks/index.d.ts" />
///<reference auto-fetched-typings="nunjucks" />
```
Or something...

Thanks

data.title: Having the ability to move the tab close button to the left of the tab
data.body:
When `workbench.editor.showTabs` is set to `false`, the document tab fills the whole width of the window.

It would be nice to have an option to move the close button to the left of the tab, so that the control UI gets closer to the sidebar.

data.title: Remove getmac-dependency
data.body: There is now `networkInterfaces` in the `os` module such that we don't need that dependency anymore. It's faster because it doesn't need to launch a command

data.body:

- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.1.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|1.1.4|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.3.8|
|sort-lines|Tyriar|1.1.0|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.0.3|
|Bookmarks|alefragnani|0.10.0|
|project-manager|alefragnani|0.12.2|
|one-monokai|azemoh|0.2.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.1.0|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.6.5|
|Angular2|johnpapa|1.0.2|
|theme-karyfoundation-themes|karyfoundation|10.0.0|
|HTMLHint|mkaufman|0.0.3|
|vscode-stylefmt|mrmlnc|2.1.0|
|Theme-1337|ms-vscode|0.1.2|
|angular2-inline|natewallace|0.0.16|
|nonbreakingspace|smlombardi|0.0.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|4.0.2|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.20.2|
|theme-tesla|smlombardi|5.2.0|
|bootstrap-3-snippets|wcwhitehead|0.0.8|
|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open JSON file where all the items are in a single line, such as [this one](http://jmp.sh/H5O8lKB)
2. try invoking "format code" `shift-option-f`
3. code is not formatted but a `Ï` is typed
4. try using the command menu: only "format css" is available.

This is new, previous versions of Insider worked fine.

data.title: Javascript syntax colouring bug
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.2 (7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f, 2016-11-21T22:14:18.217Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-47-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.7|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.3|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. make a statement using the new keyword and any constructor
2. pass a function expression into the constructor
3. add whitespace between the constructor name and the brackets.

```
new spaceBeforeArgs (() => {
    const message = "I'm coloured weirdly!";
    console.log(message);
});

```
![vs code colour bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5188481/20671440/4b917f40-b575-11e6-9712-2c7e2f4141fc.png)

data.title: Test: View Picker
data.body:
- [x] macOS @mjbvz 
- [x] Windows @mousetraps 

Complexity: 2
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15262

A new picker is added that shows viewlets, panels, output channels and terminals. You can open it via the **Open View** command or by typing `view` followed by a `space` into quick open. 

**Verify**
* you can use the picker and it makes sense to you
* the results are searchable
* Mac/Windows: pressing and holding `Ctrl+Q` you can quick navigate and release to open

data.title: Default Dark Theme highlight issue
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.7.2 - OS Version: 10.11.6 Applying the default Dark Theme on a piece of javascript code: This is clearly a bug. String highlight colour leaks past the string, to the rest of the code.

data.title: Find regex too greedy
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Linux Mint

Steps to Reproduce:
- File content: 
${a} went and bought ${b} apple. And ${c} broke them
- Find exp: \\$\\{.+\\}

The match will be:  "${a} went and bought ${b} apple. And ${c}"
Is it ok to be this greedy? Or is it there a way to change this in settings or something?
